Happy New Year to all!
Thank you, Niawen, for all people have done/are doing regarding awareness of Redhill.  Even though construction continues, awareness is needed for now, and in the future, of what did happen and is happening.
The story has to be told.

The spirit of Redhill Lives...

Also, nature and those 7 generations forward and back will not make it easy...

Your Candidate
David Heatley

Bio:

Has worked in a wide variety of jobs since starting work at the age of 13 while still a high school student, including three years in the Canadian Armed Forces, and as a blaster at the Algoma Ore Mining Company, as a hunting and fishing guide and as a home renovators 
Disabled in his last job, has become a prominent environmental and native rights activist 
Involved in the fight to save the Red Hill 
Married 16 years to Joyce Heatley and the father of three girls.

People are scattered but efforts continue in different ways.

Note: the sacred fire burnt 2003-2005, 
It still burns within each of us!

Although people have been "scattered" resistance is there! People continue to fight in different ways. The pace at which construction is done shows that they know they are wrong. 

The story continues, keep up the fight, do what you can in any way no matter how big or small.  
Niawen, Jiawen, Meegwetch, Thank you, merci, or however you say it for those contributions all have made up to now. 

Remember the greater good and keep a Good Mind, for the great purpose.

Hope is not lost, there is still greenspace. Also the speed at which they operate, they know they are wrong.  RED HILL VALLEY LIVES, in each of us and is still there.

In spirit and there is still time...don't forget.

Construction, engineering wise is not sound, environmentally of course as well.  Nature and those 7 generations back and forward, will not make the building easy...

To everyone who was/is involved, from all stages, and did what they could. Meegwetch, Jiawen, Niawen, thank you, merci.

Question:

July 4, 2005
 
Attention Chris Murray,
 
Thank you for your reply. 
I have further questions I would appreciate written answers to.
 
Please specify what type of conditions (weather and other) that would definitely limit/stop toxic material excavation activity as I am shocked that extreme summer heat/
increased smog hasn't.
 
Has Bennett Environmental in Quebec specified what they do with the PCB waste received from the City of Hamilton? Is it just held or treated?
____________________________


Response:
In terms of your first question, according to the City of Hamilton's Public Health Unit, " in regards to the summer heat or smog acting as a trigger to limit or stop activity, heat is not a parameter which is used to determine an action. A parameter of smog, Particulate Matter (PM10), is a variable which is measured in accordance with the air monitoring program. The purpose in monitoring is to determine if the worksite is generating fine particulate matter that may affect the community, not to evaluate the impact that a smog day has upon the worksite. It then follows that a high level of PM10 is alone not a reason for limiting or stopping work. Rather, an elevated level of PM10, as compared to current background levels, is a reason to limit or stop activities."
 
Further, in terms of your second question, Bennett Environmental does treat the soil before disposing of it.
 
Please feel free to contact Chris Murray or myself if you require any further information.  Thank you.
Michael R. Marini, M.A. 
Community Relations Officer-Red Hill Valley Project 
Public Works Department- City of Hamilton 
77 James Street North, Suite 320 
Hamilton, Ontario L8R 2K3 

Phone: (905) 546-2424 ext. 5620 
Fax: (905) 540-6139 
mmarini@hamilton.ca 
_______________________
First Response:

Your e-mail dated July 4, 2005 re: "more questions from concerned citizen re: RHVP details" has been forwarded to my attention.  Please note that I am in the process of obtaining the necessary information and should have an answer for you shortly.  Thank you for your patience in this matter.
Michael R. Marini, M.A. 
Community Relations Officer-Red Hill Valley Project 
Public Works Department- City of Hamilton 
77 James Street North, Suite 320 
Hamilton, Ontario L8R 2K3 

Phone: (905) 546-2424 ext. 5620 
Fax: (905) 540-6139 
mmarini@hamilton.ca

Dufferin Construction is responsible for excavation work at the Rennie Street site and the health and safety of its workers.  Air monitoring is occurring at both the site and nearby residences.  Health professionals with Hamilton's Public Health Division, Rennie Community Liaison Committee, and Red Hill Valley Project office regularly review this information to determine if or when action needs to be taken to limit/stop excavation activity.   Despite the hot weather, work is able to continue safely.
 
PCB waste is being trucked by licensed haulers to a landfill site in Quebec (Bennett Environmental) designed and regulated to accept this type of waste.  I hope this addresses your concerns.
 
Chris Murray, 
Acting Director, Red Hill Valley Project 
Public Works Department 
  
320-77 James Street North 
Hamilton, Ontario, Canada 
  
Tel.  905 546-2424 ext. 2343 
Fax  905 540-6139 
E-mail  cmurray@hamilton.ca 
www.hamilton.ca/rhvp 
______________________
Attention Chris Murray,
 
Please reply in writing to the following questions about your Red Hill Valley Project monthly update of June 2, 2005 posted on the City of Hamilton website. 
Thank you.
 
What is the policy for excavating during heat waves/smog alert days? I ask since the report states that work was likely to continue past the mid June completion date and expected to continue into July. This June has been the hottest ever and likely the smoggiest too.
 
Where is the final destination that the toxic waste from Rennie Street Landfill is to be trucked too? What happens to it once it is there?
 __________________________

Document link:

http://www.city.hamilton.on.ca/public-works/capital-planning/red-hill-valley-program/Red-Hill-Valley-Project/Whats-New/Project-Updates/2005/Project-Update-June-2-2005.pdf

Council warned suing others 'might come back on us'
By PETER VAN HARTEN
The Hamilton Spectator(Jun 25, 2005) 
Hamilton likes to sue and should be careful about a proposal to refuse to do business with people taking legal action against the city.

That's the warning from Councillor Brian McHattie who has convinced politicians to get more legal advice before deciding on imposing a city ban on dealing with anyone who is suing Hamilton or violating property or zoning bylaws.

Of late, the city has started suing people and "this might come back on us," he said.

Hamilton is pursuing legal action against the federal government and Environment Canada over approval delays for the Red Hill Valley expressway, he pointed out.

Next thing you know, McHattie said, some politician will be standing up in the House of Commons arguing that the government shouldn't have any dealings with Hamilton because of the lawsuits.

McHattie was joined by Mayor Larry Di Ianni and city solicitor Peter Barkwell yesterday in convincing committee of the whole to get more advice on a motion by Councillor Murray Ferguson calling for the ban.

Councillor Ferguson said he intended the policy only for third-party litigants, not government-to-government disputes.

In the past, Ferguson has expressed frustration that lawsuits by Yale Properties, owners of Jackson Square, affected the city's ability to move the Farmers' Market and promote redevelopment of the decaying downtown Lister Block building.

Councillor Dave Mitchell urged that the ban apply not only to lawsuits but also to zoning and bylaw violators.

Solicitor Barkwell told politicians the city already had discretionary powers not to accept tenders and requests for proposals if it wanted. Any blanket prohibition could create problems, especially in disputes between sub-contractors and contractors and in insurance matters where the city is named in suits but not directly involved.

Mayor Di Ianni told the committee that anyone who felt their dispute with the city had merit should not be prevented from doing business with it.

"We are not always right," Di Ianni said.
